awd_titl_txt: Glutamate transporter control of excitation and inhibition in the striatum
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals have the ability to learn new motor skills and convert them into motor habits. The striatum, a major part of a key motor system in the brain called basal ganglia, is known to exert a fundamental role in controlling the execution of habitual actions. What is not known is exactly how the striatum coordinates the activity of its neurons to ensure proper execution of habitual actions. Recent findings suggest that a particular neurotransmitter transporter, the neuronal glutamate transporter EAAT3, might act as a key player in controlling the time course of excitatory transmission in multiple regions of the brain, including in the striatum. This research project will determine how EAAT3 controls glutamatergic signaling and synaptic integration onto two distinct types of striatal neurons. To accomplish this goal, the investigators use a comprehensive and multidisciplinary toolbox that includes electrophysiological, optical imaging, and computer modeling approaches, as well as mice genetically-engineered that express either D1- or D2-type dopamine neurons.. The project includes training of graduate and undergraduate students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines while advancing and transforming our knowledge of striatal circuits. Inclusion of underrepresented minorities and public engagement activities are an integral part of the project, to broaden its impact with the general public.

Our ability to perform movements relies on the activity of a neuronal circuit known as the cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) pathway. Relay of information in the CSTC pathway relies on the coordinated activation of neurons in the striatum, a major node of the CSTC pathway. The striatum is largely composed of two types of long-projection neurons that express either D1 or D2 dopamine receptors. Glutamate transporters are abundantly expressed in the striatum but their role in controlling the coordinated activity of striatal neurons remains enigmatic. The first goal of this project is to determine how neuronal glutamate transporters regulate excitatory transmission in D1- and D2-expressing neurons. The second goal is to determine how these transporters shape the temporal accuracy with which these cells relay information from incoming excitatory inputs. The experimental strategies entail innovative multi-disciplinary approaches based on electrophysiology, optogenetics, imaging and computer modeling. The proposed research will generate new knowledge on the functional role of glutamate transporters in the activity patterns and dynamics of circuits implicated in habitual movement execution.

por.por_cntn:
The striatum is a major nucleus of the basal ganglia, known to control the execution of habitual actions. One of the aspects about striatal function taht remains incompletely understood is exactly how the  this brain nucleus coordinates the activity of its neurons to ensure proper execution of habitual actions. Recent findings suggest that the neuronal glutamate transporter EAAT3 might act as a key player in controlling excitation and inhibition in multiple regions of the brain, including the striatum. Therefore, the main goals in this project were to determine how EAAT3 controls excitation, inhibition and synaptic integration onto two distinct types of striatal neurons, which can be distinguished using genetically-engineered mice because of their expression of either D1 or D2 dopamine receptors. Over the course of this project, we used a comprehensive and multidisciplinary toolbox that included electrophysiology, optogenetics, viral approaches, imaging and computer modeling. Our findings indicated that EAAT3 reduces exctation and enhances inhibition only in D1 medium spiny neurons. Specifically, the only form of inhibition regulated by EAAT3 is reciprocal inhibition among D1 medium spiny neurons. Because of this finding, we could study, for the first time, the effects of this form of inhibition on synaptic integration and task switching behaviors in mice, providing a major contribution to our understanding of the functional properties of striatal circuits. We also analyzed how the geometry of small subcellular compartments can confine the local expression of glutamate transporters, and limit glutamate diffusion. Overall, we produced 12 manuscripts and 2 more are in their final stages of the submission process. The data were presented at national and international conferences for a total of 56 presentation, given by the PI, her graduate and numerous undergraduate students.

The broader impacts of this project focused on training graduate and under-graduate students in the STEM field, while also advancing and transforming our knowledge of striatal circuits. We supported the thesis dissertation of 10 students. Overall, 50+ undergraduate students were trained in our lab and many of them were from under-represented minorities. Therefore, inclusion of under-represented minorities and public engagement activities were an integral part of the project, which all served to broaden the impact of this project with the general public. We woekd in collaboration with the Alzheimer's Association to provide outreach opportunities to our neurobiology class, and organized an annual meeting of the Society of Neuroscience Hudson-Berkshire, which allowed us to bring world renowned speakers to our community and provide our trainees with the opportunity to discuss and share their science. The PI provided yearly career development opportunities, which over the last year were done in collaboration with the undergraduate Neuroscience Club at SUNY Albany. The project allowed the PI to sponsor numerous summer fellowships, for both under-represented minority students and students from neighboring colleges (Vassar, Tufts), many of which continued their post-graduate education around the country. The PI trained students to improve their leadership skills. Note that all these activities were held virtually during the pandemic, but were never interrupted, so that our trainees would not lose these unique opportunities for professional development.
